column2: ## Now we go through the loop of removing columns based on nomination stage
# To learn more about for loops, see:
# For each subject in the processed dataframe (procDf_1)
for (i in 1:nrow(procDf_1)) {
# search for empty cells in subject row of ls_nom
# if not empty, set subject row in memList to ls_nom values
memList[i,1:length(ls_nom)] <- ls_nom[i, ]
# search for empty cells in subject row of lp_nom
# if not empty, set subject row in memList to lp_nom values
memList[i,1:length(lp_nom)] <- lp_nom[i, ]
# search for empty cells in subject row of m2m_nom
# if not empty, set subject row in memList to m2m_nom values
memList[i, 1:length(m2m_nom)] <- m2m_nom[i, ]
# if empty, continue loop
if (any(is.na(m2m_nom[i, ])))
# search for empty cells in subject row of cle_nom
# if not empty, set subject row in memList to cle_nom values
memList[i,1:length(cle_nom)] <- cle_nom[i, ]
# if empty, remove row from procDf_1
if (any(is.na(m2m_nom[i, ]))) {
procDf_1 <- procDf_1 %>%
select(-c(i), )
# We just checked each set of memory nomination rows (each subject per row) to see which nomination columns were empty.
# For columns that were not empty, we extract the memories from ProcDf_1 and insert them into memList.
# For columns that were empty, we continued looking for non-empty columns to then extract those values into memList.
# We should have a memList dataframe where each row is the subject ID and their memories.
# They are now all consolidated into the same 24 columns (col 2 - 25).
# We will use this memList to create networks and for later inferences.
